meanings.def: any of the hard white structures in the mouth used for biting food
examples: I've just had a tooth out at the dentist's.
to brush/clean your teeth
tooth decay
She answered through clenched teeth (= opening her mouth only a little because of anger).
The cat sank its teeth into his finger.
She had to have a tooth pulled (= removed).
Billy's first tooth is now through.
Her smile showed crooked teeth.
Her teeth flashed as she smiled.
His pipe was firmly clamped between his teeth.
I lost three teeth in the fight.
I used to be self-conscious of my prominent teeth.
Mink have razor-sharp teeth.
She answered the phone with a cigarette between her teeth.
She wore a brace to correct her gappy teeth.
The cat came in with a mouse in its teeth.
Sugar rots your teeth.
Their teeth were chattering with cold.
Skyscrapers rose like jagged teeth.

meanings.def: a narrow, pointed part that sticks out of an object
examples: the teeth on a saw
The teeth of the cog should fit into these grooves.

meanings.def: having many weapons
to show your teeth in an aggressive and threatening way
examples: The dog bared its teeth and growled.

meanings.def: if you do something by the skin of your teeth, you only just manage to do it
examples: He escaped defeat by the skin of his teeth.

meanings.def: to do something that gives you your first experience of a particular type of work
examples: She cut her teeth on local radio.

meanings.def: to grow a new tooth
used to say that you should punish somebody by doing to them what they have done to you or to somebody else
examples: They advocate a justice system that works on the principle of an eye for an eye.

meanings.def: to fight in a very determined way for what you want
examples: The residents are fighting tooth and nail to stop the new development.
She fought tooth and nail to keep custody of the children.

meanings.def: to become very enthusiastic about something that you have started to do so that you are unlikely to stop until you have finished
to put a lot of effort and enthusiasm into something that is difficult enough to keep you interested
examples: Choose an essay topic that you can really get your teeth into.

meanings.def: used when you are saying that you want something very much
examples: I'd give my eye teeth to own a car like that.

meanings.def: to press or hit your teeth together because you feel angry; to feel very angry and upset about something, especially because you cannot get what you want
examples: He'll be gnashing his teeth when he hears that we lost the contract.
The news caused great wailing and gnashing of teeth.

meanings.def: to bite your teeth tightly together
examples: She gritted her teeth against the pain.
‘Stop it!’ he said through gritted teeth.

meanings.def: to be determined to continue to do something in a difficult or unpleasant situation
examples: It started to rain harder, but we gritted our teeth and carried on.

meanings.def: to like food that contains a lot of sugar
to be powerful and effective
used to express anger or surprise
examples: Hell’s teeth, I promised I’d be back by two.

meanings.def: despite problems, opposition, etc.
examples: The new policy was adopted in the teeth of fierce criticism.

meanings.def: in the direction that a strong wind is coming from
examples: They crossed the bay in the teeth of a howling gale.

meanings.def: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it
something that hurts somebody/something emotionally; a great disappointment
examples: The job losses are a kick in the teeth for the union.

meanings.def: to say something that is not true at all
examples: The witness was clearly lying through his teeth.

meanings.def: used to say that it is very difficult to make somebody do something
examples: It's like pulling teeth trying to get him to talk.

meanings.def: old or too old
involving opposition or competition that is violent and without sympathy
examples: nature, red in tooth and claw

meanings.def: to make somebody feel physically uncomfortable
examples: Just the sound of her voice sets my teeth on edge.

idioms.def: having many weapons
to show your teeth in an aggressive and threatening way
examples: The dog bared its teeth and growled.

idioms.idiom: by the skin of your teeth
idioms.def: if you do something by the skin of your teeth, you only just manage to do it
examples: He escaped defeat by the skin of his teeth.

idioms.def: to do something that gives you your first experience of a particular type of work
examples: She cut her teeth on local radio.

idioms.def: to grow a new tooth

idioms.idiom: an eye for an eye (and a tooth for a tooth)
idioms.def: used to say that you should punish somebody by doing to them what they have done to you or to somebody else
examples: They advocate a justice system that works on the principle of an eye for an eye.

idioms.def: to fight in a very determined way for what you want
examples: The residents are fighting tooth and nail to stop the new development.
She fought tooth and nail to keep custody of the children.

idioms.idiom: get the bit between your teeth
idioms.def: to become very enthusiastic about something that you have started to do so that you are unlikely to stop until you have finished
to put a lot of effort and enthusiasm into something that is difficult enough to keep you interested
examples: Choose an essay topic that you can really get your teeth into.

idioms.idiom: give your eye teeth for something/to do something
idioms.def: used when you are saying that you want something very much
examples: I'd give my eye teeth to own a car like that.

idioms.def: to press or hit your teeth together because you feel angry; to feel very angry and upset about something, especially because you cannot get what you want
examples: He'll be gnashing his teeth when he hears that we lost the contract.
The news caused great wailing and gnashing of teeth.

idioms.def: to bite your teeth tightly together
examples: She gritted her teeth against the pain.
‘Stop it!’ he said through gritted teeth.
It started to rain harder, but we gritted our teeth and carried on.

idioms.def: to like food that contains a lot of sugar
to be powerful and effective
used to express anger or surprise
examples: Hell’s teeth, I promised I’d be back by two.

idioms.def: despite problems, opposition, etc.
examples: The new policy was adopted in the teeth of fierce criticism.
They crossed the bay in the teeth of a howling gale.

idioms.def: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it
something that hurts somebody/something emotionally; a great disappointment
examples: The job losses are a kick in the teeth for the union.

idioms.def: to say something that is not true at all
examples: The witness was clearly lying through his teeth.

idioms.def: used to say that it is very difficult to make somebody do something
examples: It's like pulling teeth trying to get him to talk.

idioms.def: old or too old
involving opposition or competition that is violent and without sympathy
examples: nature, red in tooth and claw

idioms.def: to make somebody feel physically uncomfortable
examples: Just the sound of her voice sets my teeth on edge.

related: an eye for an eye (and a tooth for a tooth)
go over/through something with a fine-tooth/fine-toothed comb
